Award.AwardTitle: Reconciling Different Deformation Mechanisms in Adjacent Sedimentary Lithologies at Raplee and Comb Folds, Monument Upwarp, UT
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project compares and evaluates the brittle deformation (jointing in siltstone and sandstone) and the ductile deformation (shear zone development with veins and solution seams in limestone) that occurred at the outcrop scale in adjacent strata during kilometer-scale folding on the Monument Upwarp during the Laramide orogeny. The goals of the research are: 1) to describe and map the joints and conjugate shear zones at Raplee anticline and Comb monocline in southeastern Utah; and 2) to construct and evaluate continuum mechanical models using finite element methods to investigate the brittle elastic and ductile plastic deformation associated with these structures. We seek to reconcile how and why these different mechanisms were activated in close proximity and under similar loading conditions during folding, and to deduce the stress-strain behavior of the host strata. The hypothesis is that different constitutive properties and strengths led to the activation of the different mechanisms. To test this hypothesis we compare the systematic geometric features of the structures (e.g. opening distributions and shapes of veins), to the results of the numerical models. We anticipate that certain ranges of constitutive properties and states of stress will result in similarity. This will provide important insights about the mechanical behavior of sandstone and limestone, not obtainable from laboratory testing at the decimeter scale in the absence of such structures.

Folds are one of the most common geologic structures, occurring in all layered rock types at scales from hand samples to mountain ranges. Folds in sedimentary rock take on the added importance of being traps for hydrocarbons, and therefore a primary target for oil and gas exploration. Being familiar with the stiffness and strength of sedimentary rock slabs used as paving stones or counter tops, the general public must wonder how such strata is contorted into spectacular folds such as those Comb and Raplee anticlines. The proposed project addresses this question, which also is a fundamental issue for structural geology: what deformation mechanisms operate within sedimentary strata during kilometer-scale folding? One mechanism is obvious: sandstone layers are broken by brittle fractures (joints). A second mechanism is quite subtle: limestone layers lack joints, but contain shear zones, alignments of surfaces (solution seams) along which calcite has been dissolved, and orthogonal opening cracks (veins) filled with calcite. The juxtaposition of brittle (jointing) and ductile (shear zone) mechanisms in adjacent outcrops offers the opportunity to deduce how the mechanical properties of the respective formations varied at the time of folding. The interplay of detailed mapping and mechanical modeling promises to offer new insights and original concepts about rock deformation during folding and to contribute new insights for scientists working in the closely related disciplines of petroleum geology, rock mechanics, and geodynamics. In addition to the research objectives of this project, the award is supporting the training of a graduate student; includes a partnership with faculty at Dine College to organize field trips for Native American students who will participate in collecting data; and is contributing to the broadening of participation of underrepresented groups in the Earth sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds from a National Science Foundation grant to Stanford University (principal investigator for award number 1250447, David D. Pollard) supported the final two years of Solomon Seyum’s PhD studies in the department of Geological and Environmental Sciences. Solomon successfully completed the university requirements for his doctorate in August, 2015. One manuscript accepted for publication in the Journal of Structural Geology, and one manuscript in preparation for submission to a peer-reviewed journal are direct outcomes of this grant. The research has advanced the state of knowledge for structural geologists about deformation mechanisms in sedimentary rock during folding, which gives new insight for those working in the closely related disciplines of tectonics, petroleum geology, rock mechanics, and geodynamics. This grant also facilitated geological field trips to Raplee Ridge, Utah (image 1), and Ship Rock, New Mexico, for students of Diné College in the Navajo Nation who were enrolled in Professor Margaret Mayer’s Historical Geology course in 2014 and 2015.

This research was motivated by observations at Raplee Ridge, Utah, of high concentrations of meter-long opened fractures (joints) in sedimentary rock layers that are relatively absent in some adjacent rock layers, particularly limestones. Places where joints were scarce in limestone, centimeter-long veins that are closely spaced and arranged in meter-long linear arrays are the predominant structural features (image 2). Veins are fractures that have later been filled with minerals, like calcite. These particular veins are accompanied by mutually intersecting pressure solution seams, which are thin, planar features where less dissolvable minerals are concentrated after more dissolvable minerals were removed by pressure solution and transported by fluids. These observations led to the hypothesis that the different structures, joints versus veins with pressure solution seams, in adjacent sedimentary layers are a manifestation of different material properties of the layers experiencing similar forces.

Raplee Ridge and Comb Ridge in southeastern Utah are the expressions of folded marine and terrestrial sedimentary rock layers. Raplee Ridge is about 14 kilometers long and is adjacent to the 130 kilometer-long Comb Ridge that marks the eastern boundary of the regional topographic highland known as the Monument Upwarp. The package of exposed rock layers is approximately 1500 meters thick, consisting broadly of meter-thick shale, limestone, siltstone, and sandstone lithologies. The rocks range in age from 310 to 190 million years. Folding, between 70 and 40 million years ago, has inclined the layers of rock by as much as 60° from an original horizontal position. The process of folding required very large tectonic forces, resulting in the formation of joints, veins, and pressure solution seams in distinct rock layers.

There are three main sets of joints distributed across Raplee Ridge and Comb Ridge, and each joint set is differentiated by their orientation. For each set, an orientation of the tectonic force is inferred using mathematical models for the formation of joints. In general, the greatest compression is parallel with the joint plane. Therefore, there are at least three distinct compression orientations that once existed at this location, each related to a joint set.

The main scientific outcome of this project is the development of the first numerical models of veins with intersecting pressure solution seams that can reproduce measured vein shapes. These results can be used to infer the orientation of tectonic forces associated with their formation, similar to joints.
